instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP2V7_NAND: What is PP2V7_NAND? PP2V7_NAND is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_TPAD: What is PPBUS_G3H_TPAD? PPBUS_G3H_TPAD is a power rail that powers the trackpad. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
Hi, I got this board, it changes from 5v to 19,5v, tries to run, but when it gets to ,500A it goes back to 0 and stays there

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12,64
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> =12,64
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 20V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5,139
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> = 5,139
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL>= 12,64
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>= 12,64
PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3HRTC= 12,64
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL>=3,3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_WLANBT</SIGNAL>= 3,29
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>= 12,64
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_TPAD</SIGNAL>= 12,64
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> =3,3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3,3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>= 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL>= 0
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>= 1,8

Never worked on this board before, don´t know where to start... it looks pretty clean though...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: Check which big coils get voltage then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: When it’s at .500A I should check the voltages, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: Yeah, all secondary power supplies (big coils).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
L8100= ,500v (pulses on goes down)
L8410= ,015v
L8102=,900v (pulses and goes down)
L7410= 0
L7430= 0
L7210= ,900v (pulse and goes down)
L7230= ,900v (pulse and goes down)
L7290= 1,1 (pulse and goes down)
L7030= this one does wierd stuff, when usb c connected, right away you get 5,1v, then at ,500A I get 12,64v when the amperage drops, it goes to 3.3v and then to ,800v and starts droping...
L7690= 3,3v
L7670= 5,1v
L9060= 2,4v

each and every measure was taken when the board was at ,500a consumption

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: Check if you can get into DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: I was able to get the computer into DFU mode, I tried to reinstall the firmware but got stuck on the 4th step "installing system" and the a message with this error: AMrestoreErrorDomain 9 - Failed to recieve message from device. AMRestoreErrorDomain - 0x9 (9)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
Check if you get all SSD voltages.

Any history available, liquid sign on audio board, or flex/connector?

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>

are these all the SSD voltages?

No liquid, no liquid sign on audio board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: I was trying DFU  mode and found out that it only works on one of the USB C ports... when I try to put the computer in DFU when connected to the port closer to the monitor it just don´t get into DFU and even the computer to which I am connecting it gives an alert that the accesorie is not compatible, the usb c cable is original and when connected to the secondary usb c, it recognizes it with no problems...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
You should know that exists a dedicated port for DFU!
Still get the same error?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: Sorry, I didn’t, still doing the same, sometimes it shows the computer in recovery, then I put it on DFU but it can’t complete the process in neither modes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
Where did you get the board?
There should be some history fault...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message: The customer reports that it was dropped but not too hard... after that it continued working and suddenly it just stopped turning on... thats all the history I have...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 19v 0A
threads.message:
Maybe broken trace, or solder under some BGA chip.
Hopeless project, as looks like T2 issue.
